question: What does the term “ASDA” (Accelerate-Stop Distance Available) mean?

choices.choice: The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway and clearway (if provided)
The length of the take-off run available plus the length of stopway (if stopway provided)
The length of the runway plus the length of stopway available (if stopway provided)

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Takeoff Run Available (TORA): The length of the runway declared available and suitable for the ground run of an aircraft during takeoff.
  • Takeoff Distance Available (TODA): The TORA plus the length of the clearway, if provided. This represents the total distance available for takeoff.
  • Accelerate-Stop Distance Available (ASDA): The TORA plus the length of the stopway, if provided. This is the distance available for an aircraft to accelerate to decision speed and then stop safely.
  • Landing Distance Available (LDA): The length of runway declared available and suitable for the ground run of an aircraft during landing.

question: How far must a parking bay for an aircraft suspected of unlawful interference be from other parking areas or buildings?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Isolated Aircraft Parking Position:

  • An isolated aircraft parking position is designated for the parking of an aircraft known or believed to be involved in unlawful interference or needing isolation from normal aerodrome traffic.
  • The control tower must be advised of this area or areas suitable for such parking.
  • This special area must be located at least 100 meters away from any other parking area, building, or public area.
  • The position should also not be situated over underground utilities such as gas, aviation fuel, electrical, or communications cables.

question: What surface does a white-marked taxiway indicate?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Runway Markings:

  • Runway markings are typically white.
  • On runway surfaces of light color, the conspicuity of white markings can be improved by outlining them in black.
  • This enhancement helps pilots better identify markings during takeoff and landing.

question: How should runway threshold lights be configured?

choices.choice: Fixed lights showing green or white colours
Fixed unidirectional lights showing green in the direction of approach to the runway

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Key points about Runway Threshold and Wing Bar Lights:

  1. Function: These lights serve to enhance visibility and indicate the runway threshold during approach.
  2. Lighting Characteristics: They are fixed, unidirectional lights that display a green color in the direction of the approach to the runway.
  3. Placement: Positioned at the threshold of the runway and along the wing bars, they provide critical visual cues for pilots.
  4. Purpose: Their primary purpose is to guide pilots safely to the runway, especially during low visibility conditions.

question: How is the aerodrome category for rescue and fire fighting determined?

choices.choice: The over-all length of the longest aeroplane normally using the aerodromes and its maximum fuselage width
The over-all length of the longest aeroplane
The longest aeroplane maximum width only

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The aerodrome category is based on the longest aeroplanes normally using the aerodrome and fuselage width. If, after selecting the category appropriate to the longest aeroplane’s overall length, that aeroplane’s fuselage width is greater than the maximum width for that category, then one category higher is used.

\n

question: What is the purpose of a STOPWAY?

choices.choice: A landing aircraft can be stopped if overcoming the end of runway
An aircraft can be stopped in the case of an abandoned take-off
A landing aircraft can be stopped only in emergency

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Stopway (SWY): A defined rectangular area on the ground at the end of takeoff run available prepared as a suitable area in which an aircraft can be stopped in the case of an abandoned takeoff.
\nA stopway shall have the same width as the runway with which it is associated. A stopway should be prepared or constructed so as to be capable, in the event of an abandoned takeoff, of supporting the aeroplane which the stopway is intended to serve, without inducing structural damage to the aeroplane.

\n

question: What is the purpose of a LFFZ (Landing Field Fire Zone) around an aerodrome?

choices.choice: protect aircraft from low flying aircraft
protect aircraft from low flying aircraft in military areas

subject: Regulations
explanation:
To protect the safety of aircraft against the hazardous effects of laser emitters, the following protected zones should be established around aerodromes.
. a laser-beam free flight zone (LFFZ)
. a laser-beam critical flight zone (LCFZ)
. a laser-beam sensitive flight zone (LSFZ)

question: How should high-intensity obstacle lights be installed?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
High Intensity Lights:

  1. Function: High intensity obstacle lights are used to enhance the visibility of obstacles for aircraft, ensuring safety during flight operations.
  2. Lighting Characteristics: These lights are flashing white lights, designed to attract attention.
  3. Flashing Rate: The lights should flash simultaneously at a rate between 40 and 60 flashes per minute.
  4. Placement: They are located on objects that may pose a hazard to aircraft, such as tall buildings or towers.

question: What does the abbreviation PAPI stand for?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Precision Approach Path Indicators (PAPI):

  1. Function: PAPI provides glide path guidance as an aid during the visual phase of a precision approach, specifically after the Decision Height (DH).
  2. Lighting System: The system consists of four light units that emit either red or white light.

question: What color is the aerodrome beacon at a land aerodrome?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Aerodrome Beacon:

– An aerodrome beacon shows flashes of light to help pilots locate the aerodrome.

– For land aerodromes, the beacon colors are white or white and green.

– For water aerodromes, the beacon colors are white or white and yellow.

– Beacons are required at night if one or more of the following conditions exist:
– Aircraft predominantly navigate by visual means.
– Reduced visibilities are frequent.
– It is difficult to locate the aerodrome due to surrounding lights or terrain.

question: How are taxiway and aircraft stand markings indicated?
subject: Regulations
explanation: Taxiway markings and aircraft stand markings are yellow. If there is a need to enhance conspicuity, the lines may be outlined in black.

question: What is the standard composition of a PAPI system?

choices.choice: Two wing bars of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced
A wing bar of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced
Two wing bars of 6 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The PAPI system shall consist of a wing bar of four sharp transition multi-lamp (or paired single lamp) units equally spaced. The system shall be located on the left side of the runway unless it is physically impracticable to do so (See Fig. 10).
\nNote:- Where a runway is used by aircraft requiring visual roll guidance which is not provided by other external means, a second wing bar may be provided on the opposite

\n

question: How should runway end lights be installed?

choices.choice: Fixed unidirectional lights showing red in the direction of the runway

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Runway end lights indicate the end of a runway equipped with runway edge lights.
  • These lights are fixed, unidirectional, and show a red color in the direction of the runway.
  • They are placed in a line at right angles to the runway axis, as close to the end as possible.
  • The installation should consist of at least six lights for clear visibility.

question: Where should aiming point markings be placed on a runway?

choices.choice: each approach end of paved instrument runway
paved taxy track joining precision approach runway
paved runways not provided with touch down zone markings

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Aiming Point Marking:

  • The aiming point marking indicates the position of the origin of the visual glide slope, such as the PAPI and the ILS glide path (GP) transmitter.
  • It serves as a reference point for pilots during landing to align with the correct approach path.
  • An aiming point marking is required at each approach end of code 2, 3, or 4 paved instrument runways.
  • This marking ensures precise visual guidance during landings.

4o

question: How should aerodrome signs be configured?

choices.choice: mandatory instruction signs, black backgrounds with red inscriptions
information signs, yellow or black background with black or yellow inscriptions
mandatory instruction signs, red background with black inscriptions

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Information Signs feature a black inscription on a yellow background, while Location Signs have a yellow inscription on a black background and include a yellow border if standalone.

\n

question: How should low-intensity obstacle lights be installed on mobile objects?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Low-intensity obstacle light
Low-intensity obstacle lights on fixed objects, Type A and B shall be fixed-red lights. Type E shall be flashing red lights. They shall be spaced at longitudinal intervals not exceeding 45 m.
Low-intensity obstacle lights, displayed on vehicles associated with emergency or security shall be flashing-blue and those displayed on other vehicles shall be flashing- yellow.
Low-intensity obstacle lights displayed on follow-me vehicles shall be flashing
yellow.

question: How is VASIS used for runway approaches?

choices.choice: not served by visual approach aids
not served by non visual approach aids
whether or not the runway is served by visual approach aids or by non-visual aids, where turbo jet operations take place

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Runway Usage: Used by turbojet or other aircraft with similar approach guidance requirements.
  • Pilot Judgement Issues: Difficulty in judging approach due to:
    • Inadequate visual guidance (e.g., over water or featureless terrain).
    • Misleading visual information from surrounding terrain or runway slopes.
  • Hazardous Objects: Presence of objects in the approach area that may pose a risk if non-visual aids aren’t available.
  • Runway Ends: Physical conditions at either end of the runway may pose hazards in case of undershooting or overrunning.
  • Turbulence Risk: Terrain or meteorological conditions that could cause unusual turbulence during approach.

question: What color are emergency vehicles operating on the maneuvering area?

choices.choice: A single conspicuous colour, preferably red or yellowish green

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Vehicles and Mobile Objects. When mobile objects are marked by colour, a single conspicuous colour, preferably red or yellowish green for emergency vehicles and yellow for service vehicles should be used. Aerodrome operators are responsible for ensuring that vehicles on the movement area of an aerodrome are lit and/or marked as required irrespective of ownership. These include maintenance vehicles, ATC vehicles, ‘Follow Me’ vehicles, aircraft towing vehicles, refuellers etc.

\n

question: What color are apron safety line markings?

choices.choice: A contrasting colour from the taxiway markings

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Apron Safety Lines:

  • Apron safety lines, while not strictly taxiway markings, enhance the safe movement of aircraft into and out of parking stands.
  • If all ground equipment and vehicles are parked behind the apron safety lines, pilots or marshals can ignore those obstacles when parking aircraft.
  • These lines must be of a conspicuous color that contrasts with the color used for aircraft stand markings.

question: How are runway centreline lights configured from threshold to 300 m from runway end?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Runway Centre Line Lights:

– Runway centre line lights are required on runways used for take-offs with operating minimums below an RVR (Runway Visual Range) of approximately 400 meters.

– These lights are fixed, variable intensity white lights.

– Over the last 900 meters from the runway end, the lights alternate between red and white from 900 meters to 300 meters.

– From 300 meters to the runway end, the lights are all red to indicate the runway’s proximity to its end.

question: How many red lights must a pilot see on final approach when following a PAPI glide path?
subject: Regulations
explanation: \n

question: How is a stopway defined for an abandoned take-off?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Stopway:

  • A defined rectangular area at the end of the take-off run available.
  • It is prepared and designated as a suitable area where an aircraft can be stopped in the case of a discontinued take-off.
  • The stopway enhances safety by providing additional distance for the aircraft to decelerate if take-off is aborted.

question: What is the function of the ARIWS system?

choices.choice: warning a pilot about bird activity on take off path
cautioning a pilot about wind shear on finals in real time
warning a pilot about runway incursion in near real time

subject: Regulations
explanation:
ARIWS shall provide autonomous detection of a potential incursion or of the occupancy of an active runway and a direct warning to a flight crew or vehicle. When an aircraft is departing from a runway (rolling) or arriving at a runway (short final), red warning lights at the entrances will illuminate, indicating that it is unsafe to enter or cross the runway. When an aircraft is aligned on the runway for take-off and another aircraft or vehicle enters or crosses the runway, red warning lights will illuminate at the threshold area, indicating that is unsafe to start the take-off roll.

\n

question: What is the purpose of a clearway?

choices.choice: Reduce the risk of damage to aircraft running off a runway
Protect aircraft during take-off or landing operations
Permit aircraft to make a portion of its initial climb to a specific height

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Clearway (CWY): A defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may make a portion of its initial climb to a specified height.

\n

A clearway should extend laterally to a distance of at least 75 m on each side of the extended centre line of the runway. The ground in a clearway should not project over a plane having an upward slope of 1.25%. An object situated on a clearway which may endanger aeroplanes in the air should be regarded as an obstacle and should be removed.

\n

question: What light is shown by an aerodrome identification beacon at a land aerodrome?

choices.choice: White and green colour identification given by Morse code
Green colour identification given by Morse code
Blue colour identification given by Morse code

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Identification Beacon Details:

  Purpose: An identification beacon is used at an aerodrome to assist aircraft in identifying the aerodrome during night operations when it cannot be easily seen from the air by other means.

   Morse Code: The beacon provides identification of the aerodrome through Morse code signals.

  Flashing Green: At a land aerodrome, the identification beacon shows Flashing Green light.

This system helps pilots identify the aerodrome type and location, particularly at night or in low visibility conditions.

question: How is a paved pre-threshold area greater than 60 m marked if unsuitable for aircraft use?

choices.choice: By white arrows directing approaching aircraft to the displaced threshold

subject: Regulations
explanation: \n

question: Which system represents an abbreviated precision approach path indicator?

choices.choice: Ten light units arranged on one side of the runway in the form of a single wing bar of four light units, with a bisecting longitudinal line of six lights
Twenty light units symmetrically disposed about the runway centre line in the form of two wing bars of four light units each, with bisecting longitudinal lines of six lights
A wing bar of 2 sharp transition multi-lamp units normally located on the left side of the runway unless it is physically impracticable to do so

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The APAPI system shall consist of a wing bar of two sharp transition multi-lamp (or paired single lamp) units. The system shall be located on the left side of the runway unless it is physically impracticable to do so.
\nNote: – Where a runway is used by aircraft requiring visual roll guidance which is not provided by other external means, a second wing bar may be provided on the opposite side of the runway.

\n

question: What colors are mandatory instruction signs on an aerodrome?

choices.choice: White inscription on a red background
Yellow inscription on a black background
Black inscription on a yellow background

subject: Regulations
explanation:
A mandatory instruction sign consists of white letters/numbers on a red
background. The inscription on a runway designation sign consists of the runway designator. The inscription on a category I, II or III or joint II/III instrument approach holding position sign consists of the runway designator followed by CAT I, CAT II, CAT III, or CAT II/III, as appropriate. The inscription on a taxi-holding position sign shall consist of the taxiway designation and number.

question: How is a white board with red letters on taxiway edge interpreted?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
A mandatory instruction sign consists of white letters/numbers on a red
background

question: What are “instrument runways” used for?

choices.choice: Non precision approach runways, precision approach runways category I, II and III
Instrument approach runways, precision approach runways category I, II and III
Precision approach runways category I, II and III

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Instrument Runway. An instrument runway is one to which instrument departure and approach procedures are applied. For departing traffic, the instrument departure procedure will be defined in the form of a SID. For arriving traffic, instrument runways are sub-divided into:

• Precision runways (using ILS, MLS or PAR approaches)

• Non-precision (using VOR, NDB, SRA or ILS in azimuth only approaches)

question: How should taxiway centreline lights be installed, excluding exit taxiways?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Taxiway centre line lights are fixed, variable intensity lights that show green and are visible only to aircraft on or near the taxiway.
  • Within the ILS/MLS critical area, lights alternate between green and yellow, and the same pattern applies to high-speed exit taxiways.
  • When aircraft may use the same centre line in both directions, all lights will show green to approaching aircraft for clarity and safety.

question: How many stripes are required on each side of a 45 m wide runway’s centreline?
subject: Regulations
explanation: \n

question: What is the length of a precision approach lighting system for a CAT II runway?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• The Precision Approach Category II/III Lighting System is installed at aerodromes conducting Category II and III approaches to assist pilots during low visibility.
  • The approach lighting systems are typically 900 meters long for both categories.
  • They provide elements of attitude information, helping maintain the correct approach path.

question: How should runway edge lights be installed?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Runway Edge Lights: Runway edge lights are fixed, variable intensity white lights showing in the direction from which approaches are made.

\n

question: Taxiway centerline lights, excluding those on exit taxiways, shall be:
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Taxiway centre line lights on taxiway other than an exit taxiway and on a runway forming part of standard taxi-route shall be fixed lights showing green with beam dimensions such that the light is visible only from aeroplanes on or in the vicinity of the taxiway.

\n

question: Which Chicago Convention Annex specifies minimum aerodrome design standards?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Annex 1 – Personnel Licensing
  • Annex 2 – Rules of the Air
  • Annex 3 – Meteorological Services
  • Annex 4 – Aeronautical Charts
  • Annex 5 – Units of Measurement
  • Annex 6 – Operation of Aircraft
  • Annex 7 – Aircraft Nationality and Registration Marks
  • Annex 8 – Airworthiness of Aircraft
  • Annex 9 – Facilitation
  • Annex 10 – Aeronautical Telecommunications
  • Annex 11 – Air Traffic Services
  • Annex 12 – Search and Rescue
  • Annex 13 – Aircraft Accident and Incident Investigation
  • Annex 14 – Aerodromes
  • Annex 15 – Aeronautical Information Services
  • Annex 16 – Environmental Protection
  • Annex 17 – Security
  • Annex 18 – The Safe Transportation of Dangerous Goods by Air
  • Annex 19 – Safety Management

question: What is a “barrette” in aerodrome design?

choices.choice: Three or more ground lights closely spaced together to appear as a bar of lights
A frangible structure on which approach lights are fixed

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Barrettes are groups of three or more lights arranged in a bar formation, used in runway lighting systems for improved visibility. They can be arranged as single light units or as bars.

\n

question: What do alternating yellow/green taxiway centreline lights indicate?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Taxiway Centre Line Lights:

  • Taxiway centre line lights are fixed, variable intensity lights that show green and are visible only from the aeroplanes on or in the vicinity of the taxiway.
  • Within the ILS/MLS critical/sensitive area, the centre line lights alternate between green and yellow.

question: How is a location sign displayed on an aerodrome?

choices.choice: Red writing on a white background
Yellow writing on a black background
Black writing on a yellow background

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Location Signs consist of an inscription in yellow on a black background and where it is a stand-alone sign, has a yellow border.

\n

question: On a PAPI, what does the wing bar indicate when approaching the slope?

choices.choice: Two red lights and two white lights
Three white lights and one red light

subject: Regulations
explanation: \n

question: How is the Accelerate-Stop Distance Available (ASDA) defined?

choices.choice: The distance from the start of the take-off run to the last point capable of bearing the full weight of the aircraft under normal operating conditions
The distance from the start of the take-off run to the end of the stopway
The area beyond the end of the prepared surface only available to aircraft stopping in an emergency

subject: Regulations
explanation:
ASDA (Accelerate-Stop Distance Available):

  • Definition: The distance from the start of the take-off run to the nearest point in the direction of take-off at which the aircraft cannot roll over the surface and be brought to rest in an emergency without risk of accident.
  • Previous Terminology: ASDA was previously referred to as EDA (Emergency Distance Available).
  • Components: ASDA typically consists of TORA (Take-Off Run Available) plus any available stopway.

question: How is crash/rescue service provision categorized based on aeroplane characteristics?

choices.choice: Overall length and maximum takeoff mass
Maximum number of passengers on board

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The aerodrome category is based on the longest aeroplanes normally using the aerodrome and fuselage width. If, after selecting the category appropriate to the longest aeroplane’s overall length, that aeroplane’s fuselage width is greater than the maximum width for that category, then one category higher is used.

\n
